conclusion: The light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The task is to analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves forward above the objects.
The image shows four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Shadow A is cast by a lamp-like object, shadow B by a waffle-like object, shadow C by a cake-like object, and shadow D by an ice cream-like object.
When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects horizontally but remains above them.
As the light source moves forward, the angle at which light rays hit the objects changes.
Shadows will generally move backward (away from the objects) because the light rays are now hitting the objects from a more forward angle.
The size of the shadows depends on the angle of the light rays and the distance between the light source and the objects.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of incidence decreases, which typically results in longer shadows.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward and become larger as the light source moves forward.
Shadow A moves backward and becomes larger.
Shadow B moves backward and becomes larger.
Shadow C moves backward and becomes larger.
Shadow D moves backward and becomes larger.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward and become larger.
